headline: Sony, Zee agree to enter into good faith negotiations to extend cut-off date
content:
Sony and Zee have decided to enter into good faith negotiations as required under the Merger Cooperation Agreement (MCA) to discuss the
extension
of the date required to make the merger scheme effective by a reasonable period.
On December 17, ZEEL asked Sony Group companies Culver Max Entertainment (CMEPL), also known as SPNI, and Bangla Entertainment (BEPL) to extend the date.
“The company is in receipt of a communication from CMEPL and BEPL that they will enter into good-faith negotiations as required under the merger cooperation agreement (MCA) entered among the parties, the company, CMEPL, and BEPL, to discuss the extension of the date required to make the scheme effective by a reasonable period of time,” ZEEL said in a BSE filing on Wednesday, December 20.
“As noted in our statement yesterday, we are required to meet with Zee to discuss the possibility of extending the deadline per our agreement, and we look forward to hearing their proposals. We have no further comment,” an SPNI spokesperson said.
Earlier, Sony Pictures Networks India (SPNI) said it hasn’t yet decided on extending the December 21 deadline to complete the merger with
Zee Entertainment Enterprises Ltd
(ZEEL).

In a statement, the Sony Group Corporation-owned company said it looks forward to hearing ZEEL’s proposals and how it plans to meet the remaining key conditions.
“Zee’s notice to the Bombay Stock Exchange and the National Stock Exchange of India dated December 17 is an acknowledgement that they will not be able to meet the December 21, 2023, deadline to close the SPNI/ZEE merger,” the SPNI statement read.
It added that the ZEEL notice triggers an existing contractual provision in the deal that allows for both parties to discuss the possibility of extending the deadline.
“SPNI is required to start those conversations but has not yet agreed to a deadline extension. We look forward to hearing Zee’s proposals and how they plan to complete the remaining critical closing conditions,” the company said.
On December 17, ZEEL asked SPNI and Bangla Entertainment, which is owned by SPNI, to extend the date for concluding their merger. ZEEL disclosed this in a regulatory filing on Sunday.
The Sony-Zee merger has received all key approvals, including that of the Competition Commission of India, the National Company Law Tribunal and the stock exchanges.
However, differences between Sony and Zee over the proposed appointment of Goenka as the merged entity’s MD and CEO have delayed the merger.
As reported first by ET, Sony is not keen on him heading the merged entity due to the Sebi probe. Sony is pushing for the appointment of SPNI MD and CEO NP Singh as CEO of the new entity.
Goenka has said the merger scheme that was agreed between the two parties should be implemented in its original form.
“From our perspective, we are committed to ensuring that all points in the Composite Scheme of Arrangement are duly addressed,” Goenka had said during Zee’s earnings call on November 9. “We recognise the value that this merger holds, and our focus remains on unlocking this opportunity for all the shareholders.”
As per the merger scheme agreed between the two, Goenka was to serve as MD and CEO of Sony-Zee for a period of five years from the effective date, subject to terms and conditions.
Sony and Zee signed a merger agreement in December 2021. It was anticipated to conclude in eight to 10 months. In May, Sony chairman and CEO Kenichiro Yoshida said the merger would conclude by September 30. That deadline was breached due to the legal cases filed by lenders against ZEEL.
If completed, the merger will lead to the creation of a multibillion-dollar media powerhouse with a leading position in TV, OTT, and content creation. FY23 financials show that ZEEL and Sony's combined revenue was almost Rs 15,000 crore.
Sony will indirectly own 50.86% of the new company, while other ZEEL shareholders will hold a 45.15% stake and the ZEEL founders would have 3.99%. The merged entity will get a fund infusion of $1.5 billion from Sony.

headline: 'NewsClick' claims its bank accounts frozen by I-T dept
content:
Online news portal "
NewsClick
" claimed on Tuesday that its bank accounts have been frozen by the income-tax department and it will undertake legal measures against this "unjust and cruel" action. There was no immediate response from the I-T authorities.
"As of the evening of December 18, 'NewsClick' has been unable to make any bank payments due to action by the
Income Tax Department
.
"This action, which has virtually frozen our accounts, appears to be a continuation of the administrative-legal siege of the news portal, which began with the
Enforcement Directorate
(ED) raids in February 2021, followed by an IT department survey in September 2021 and the October 3, 2023 crackdown by the
Delhi Police Special Cell
," the portal said in a statement on its website.
It said the organisation did not receive any intimation of the freezing of accounts and the staff discovered it by chance while trying to make routine payments on Monday evening.
"As a result of this high-handed action, salaries of all employees, journalists, videographers and administrative and support staff and consultants and contributors cannot be paid, including for the 19 days of December they have already worked," the portal said.

headline: Amazon in talks to invest in Diamond Sports: Report
content:
Amazon
is in talks to invest in
regional-sports programmer
Diamond Sports, a move that would advance the e-commerce giant's aggressive push into
sports content
, the Wall Street Journal reported on Monday, citing people familiar with the matter.
Diamond Sports Group, which carries the games of more than 40 major sports teams across the United States and filed for bankruptcy earlier this year, is actively negotiating with Amazon about a strategic investment and a multi-year streaming partnership, according to the report.
If an agreement is reached, Amazon's Prime Video platform would eventually become the streaming home for Diamond's games, the Wall Street Journal reported.
Diamond, which has the local rights to about half the teams in Major League Baseball and the National Basketball Association and about a third of the
National Hockey League
teams, would continue operating its cable networks through its existing partnerships, according to the report.
It isn't clear how much money Amazon is planning to invest or at what valuation, and Diamond has received support from a select group of creditors for proceeding with the talks, the Wall Street Journal said.
Live Events
Diamond Sports' parent company
Sinclair Broadcast
declined to comment, while Amazon and Diamond Sports did not immediately respond to Reuters' requests for comment.
(Reporting by Arsheeya Bajwa in Bengaluru; Editing by Shounak Dasgupta)

Economic Times WhatsApp channel

headline: Sony-Zee merger: Sony yet to agree to a deadline extension to create $10 billion media behemoth
content:
Sony has yet to agree to a deadline extension for merger with Zee and is looking forward to hearing the Indian media company's proposals and how they plan to complete the remaining critical closing conditions.
Sony's statement comes after
Zee Entertainment Enterprises Ltd
(ZEEL) earlier this week requested Sony Group companies to extend the date for concluding their merger as the December 21 cut-off date looms large.
"ZEE’s notice to the Bombay Stock Exchange and the National Stock Exchange of India dated December 17 is an acknowledgement that they will not be able to meet the December 21, 2023 deadline to close the SPNI/ZEE merger. The notice triggers an existing contractual provision in the deal that allows for both parties to discuss the possibility of extending the deadline," Sony said in the statement.
"SPNI is required to start those conversations but has not yet agreed to a deadline extension. We look forward to hearing ZEE’s proposals and how they plan to complete the remaining critical closing conditions,” it added.
Shares of
Zee Entertainment
hit day's low of Rs 267.25 apiece on BSE Sensex.
Live Events
Karan Taurani, analyst at Elara Capital, said, the negotiations between both parties could be resolved over the next 3-4 weeks, post which MIB (Ministry of Information and Broadcasting), record date, delisting/relisting process may take another 6-8 weeks.
"We therefore believe that the merged company could get listed by Mar/Apr’24," he said.
Sony and Zee signed a merger agreement in December 2021. The deal was anticipated to conclude in 8-10 months. However, two years down the line, it is yet to be completed due to the cases filed by financial institutions against ZEEL and the Sebi order against the company’s promoters.
Once completed, the merger will lead to the creation of a $10 billion media powerhouse with a leading position in TV, OTT, and content creation. The FY23 financials show that ZEEL and Sony's combined revenue was almost Rs 15,000 crore. The Sony-Zee deal sought to create India’s biggest entertainment company with the financial muscle to challenge global powerhouses, including Netflix Inc. and Amazon.com Inc., as well as local conglomerates such as
Reliance Industries Ltd
which is striking a deal with Disney.
The deal will help expand Sony’s media business in the world’s most populous country, with over 75 television channels and a market share of 37%, ahead of Disney-owned Star’s 24%, according to a note from brokerage firm Motilal Oswal Financial Services Ltd. The Sony-Zee behemoth will directly compete in a near-duopoly with Reliance-Disney joint venture which is in the works.
However, the deal has run into various problems.
Creditors
IDBI Bank
and Axis Finance had earlier filed pleas against the merger of Zee Entertainment Enterprise with Culver Max Entertainment, formerly Sony Pictures Networks India. They had challenged the August 10, 2023, order of the Mumbai bench of the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) to approve the merger. The NCLT, in its decision to approve the merger, rejected requests from financial institutions like
IDBI
Trusteeship, IDBI Bank, Axis Finance, JC Flowers Asset Reconstruction Co, and Imax Corp.
IDBI and Axis Finance contested this decision by appealing to the NCLAT.
On December 15, NCLAT declined to issue a stay order on the merger. The tribunal has, however, issued notice in the plea challenging the mega merger. It has listed the case for hearing on January 8. This means the merger is out of the danger zone but not the shadow of the legal suit.

headline: Dish TV appoints Sunil Khanna, Ravi Bhushan Puri as directors
content:
Direct-to-home (DTH) operator
Dish TV India
has approved the appointment of
Sunil Khanna
as an independent director and
Ravi Bhushan Puri
as executive director.
The company said the approval of the shareholders will be sought in terms of applicable regulatory provisions. It added that the appointment will be valid from the effective date until September 30, 2024.
The appointments will become effective on the date of receipt of the approval of the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (MIB) or the date on which the number of
directors
on the board falls below the statutory minimum number of three directors, whichever is earlier.
Dish TV said Puri will not be entitled to any additional remuneration in respect of the aforesaid appointment, and he will continue to draw remuneration as ‘Corporate Head—Broadcasting' of the company.
Earlier, the National Stock Exchange (
BSE
) and the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) had imposed fines of over Rs 10 lakh on
Dish TV
for board composition-related violations.
Live Events
Dish TV's board strength has been less than the SEBI-mandated six directors since March 3 due to the non-approval of the appointment of four independent directors by the company's shareholders at the Extraordinary General Meeting (EGM) held on March 3 and the resignation of independent director Zohra Chatterji with effect from June 2.
The company had said that it has taken the required steps to ensure compliance with Regulations 17(1) and 19 of the Listing Regulations, and the said non-compliance in the reduction of directors is beyond its control.
Dish TV, at its meeting held on September 21, 2023, appointed Aanchal David as Independent Director of the Company with effect from September 26, 2023, subject to shareholders’ approval.
Further, at its meeting held on September 29, 2023, the company appointed Rajesh Sahni and Virender Kumar Tagra as non-executive, non-independent directors of the company with effect from September 29, 2023, subject to shareholders’ approval.
The company also re-appointed Shankar Aggarwal as Independent Director of the Company for a second term of 5 years, with effect from October 25, 2023, subject to shareholders’ approval at its meeting held on October 21, 2023.
Dish TV will be convening an EGM of the shareholders on December 22 at 12:30 pm through video conferencing.

headline: Why the birth of a $10 bn media & entertainment behemoth still buffering up
content:
The plot has thickened for India's media & entertainment (M&E) sector. A deal which would create a $10 billion media and entertainment (M&E) giant has run into various problems. Merger of Japan's
Sony
group's Indian arm Sony Pictures Networks India (now known as Culver Max Entertainment) and
Zee
Entertainment Enterprises Ltd. is likely to be put off by several months. Zee has asked Sony to push back the deadline of December 21, 2023, for the merger which was inked on December 22, 2021.
The Sony-Zee deal sought to create India’s biggest entertainment company with the financial muscle to challenge global powerhouses, including
Netflix
Inc. and Amazon.com Inc., as well as local conglomerates such as Reliance Industries Ltd which is striking a deal with Disney.
If the deal is done, it will help expand Sony’s media business in the world’s most populous country, with over 75 television channels and a market share of 37%, ahead of Disney-owned Star’s 24%, according to a note from brokerage firm Motilal Oswal Financial Services Ltd. The Sony-Zee behemoth will directly compete in a near-duopoly with Reliance-Disney joint venture which is in the works.
In December 2021, Sony and Zee signed definitive agreements to merge. Sony will indirectly hold a majority of 50.86% of the combined company; the founders of ZEEL will hold 3.99%; and the other ZEEL shareholders will hold a 45.15% stake. The deal was anticipated to conclude in 8-10 months. However, two years down the line, it is yet to be completed due to regulatory investigation and legal suits, among other things, involving Zee and its promoters including MD & CEO Punit Goenka.
Incidentally, Zee has asked Sony to push back the deadline of December 21 a day after its annual general meeting on Saturday, where two of its special resolutions to reappoint Vivek Mehra and Sasha Mirchandani as independent directors were rejected by the shareholders.
Live Events
The challenge by creditors
In August, the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) allowed the merger of Zee and Sony. The tribunal also dismissed all objections regarding the merger. It heard arguments from creditors, including Axis Finance, JC Flower Asset Reconstruction Co, IDBI Bank, Imax Corp and IDBI Trusteeship.
Zee and Sony had approached the tribunal for sanctioning the merger after obtaining permissions from National Stock Exchange, BSE and sectoral regulators such as the Competition Commission of India and the Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi). However, the process stopped at the tribunal when a few creditors raised objections. Several creditors of Essel Group raised objections against the non-compete clause added to the scheme.
In September, creditors IDBI Bank and Axis Finance challenged the August order of NCLT to approve the merger and asked for a stay on it. Earlier, the Bombay High Court had dismissed an application filed by Axis Finance to implead Zee, Essel Mauritius, and Sony in its commercial summary suit against Zee promoter Subhash Chandra Goenka and others. The company was seeking to recover Rs 146 crore from Subhash Chandra Goenka.
A few days ago, NCLT declined to issue a stay order on the merger, ET Now reported. The tribunal has, however, issued notice in the plea challenging the mega merger. It has listed the case for hearing on January 8. This means the merger is out of the danger zone but not the shadow of the legal suit.
The Sebi overhang
Though the merger has received all the key approvals, things are stuck on the promoter's status: the differences between Sony and Zee over the appointment of Punit Goenka -- Subhash Goenka's son -- as the proposed merged entity's MD & CEO. As reported first by ET, Sony had told Goenka that he can't be the MD & CEO of the proposed entity since he continues to be under the Sebi investigation for alleged misappropriation of funds. Sony is now pushing for the appointment of its long-time India executive, NP Singh, as the CEO of the new entity.
But Zee insists that Punit Goenka will helm the new entity, as agreed in the pact signed in 2021. Sony is reportedly wary of his appointment given the Sebi probe against him. Sebi had alleged in June that Zee faked the recovery of loans to cover private financing deals by its founder, Subhash Chandra. Chandra and his son, Goenka, “abused their position” and siphoned off funds, Sebi alleged in an interim order. While Goenka got a reprieve from NCLT against the Sebi order (NCLT had earlier barred him from being an executive or director in a listed company), reportedly Sony still views the ongoing probe as an overhanging corporate governance issue.
What lies ahead for the deal?
Despite various regulatory and legal challenges, deal is not likely to fall through, "As per our assessment, extension in the merger timeline won’t have a major regulatory hurdle, as the NCLT approval is not time-bound, and this is only a mutually agreed date between two parties subject to shareholder and Board approvals; further appeals filed by Axis and other lenders in NCLAT too won’t negatively impact merger, as NCLT approval is without any conditions," Elara Capital SVP and media analyst Karan Taurani has told ET.
Earlier, lawyer Abhishek Malhotra had listed potential outcomes for the merger deal. In the first scenario, while the Sebi probe is on, someone from Sony might become the CEO of the merged entity, and the CFO might be from Zee. They can take this arrangement forward and change it back to the original understanding as soon as Punit gets the clean chit. The second scenario could be that Punit nominates someone else from Zee as the CEO of the merged entity.
In the third scenario, Punit might say that there's no impediment to him being the MD & CEO since there is a stay currently on the Sebi order. He might argue that the Sebi probe could last longer than eight months, so let him be the MD & CEO, and the probe can continue.
In an interview with ET in June, Punit Goenka had said that the merger would take place whether he was the CEO or not.

Economic Times WhatsApp channel
)

headline: BBC ex-staffers' firm collective newsroom ropes in MSKA & Associates as statutory auditor
content:
Collective Newsroom, a firm formed by ex-BBC staffers to help
BBC India
comply with foreign direct investment (
FDI
) norms in digital news, has appointed CA firm MSKA & Associates as its first statutory auditor, the company's regulatory filings show.
MSKA & Associates will audit the newly formed company's annual accounts for FY24. Incorporated on October 27, the New Delhi headquartered company has two directors, Rashi Sehgal and Prabhkirtan Singh Sehgal.
Four
BBC
staff members-Rupa Jha, Mukesh Sharma, Sanjoy Majumder, and Sara Hassan-left the company on December 12 and formed Collective Newsroom to allow BBC World Service India to comply with the 26% limit on foreign ownership in India.
ET had first reported that BBC World Service India is restructuring its shareholding to meet the foreign ownership norms.
The BBC has given Collective Newsroom the responsibility of creating digital content in India, its six Indian language services, and an English-language YouTube channel for Indian viewers across the globe. The BBC provides content in six Indian languages, including Hindi, Marathi, Gujarati, Punjabi, Tamil, and Telugu.

headline: Zee Entertainment sends letter to Sony Group Corporation, requesting an extension of cutoff to complete merger
content:
Zee Entertainment Enterprises Ltd
(ZEEL) has requested Sony Group companies to extend the date for concluding their merger as the December 21 cut-off date looms large.
In a regulatory filing on Sunday, ZEEL said it has requested Sony Group Corporation-owned Culver Max Entertainment Pvt Ltd (CMEPL) and Bangla Entertainment Pvt Ltd (BEPL) “to extend the date required to make the scheme effective as per the terms of the merger cooperation agreement” dated December 22, 2021.
Once Sony agrees to extend the date, the two parties will jointly decide the new cut-off date, people aware of the development told ET.
The merger of ZEEL, Culver Max (formerly Sony Pictures Networks India), and Bangla Entertainment would create a multi-billion-dollar media giant that had combined revenues of roughly Rs 15,000 crore in FY23.
Elara Capital SVP and media analyst Karan Taurani said the probability of the merger going through remains high.
Live Events
“As per our assessment, extension in the merger timeline won’t have a major regulatory hurdle as the NCLT approval is not time-bound, and this is only a mutually agreed date between two parties, subject to shareholder and board approvals,” he said. “Appeals filed by Axis and other lenders in NCLAT, too, won’t negatively impact the merger as NCLT approval is without any conditions,” Taurani added.
ZEEL has sent the letter to Sony a day after its annual general meeting (AGM), where two of its special resolutions to reappoint Vivek Mehra and Sasha Mirchandani as independent directors were rejected by the shareholders.
On December 14, Adesh Kumar Gupta had decided to quit as the non-executive, non-independent director of ZEEL.
Gupta was part of the firm’s special merger implementation committee, which was formed to oversee its merger with Sony and includes top officials including managing director and CEO
Punit Goenka
.
The Sony-Zee merger has received all the key approvals, including from the Competition Commission of India, the National Company Law Tribunal, and the stock exchanges.
However, differences between Sony and Zee over the proposed appointment of Punit Goenka as the merged entity’s MD and CEO have delayed the merger.
As reported first by ET, Sony has told Goenka that he can’t be the MD & CEO of the proposed entity since he continues to be under the Securities and Exchange Board of India's (Sebi) investigation for alleged misappropriation of funds.
Sony is pushing for the appointment of its long-time India executive
NP Singh
as CEO of the new entity.
“Sony is trying its best to convince Goenka to make way for Singh and has offered him an advisory role in the merged company, along with a higher cash payout in the form of a non-compete fee,” said a top media executive who is aware of the discussions between the two parties. “Goenka, however, has stuck to his guns, so far at least,” the person added.
According to a media expert, Sony’s concerns over Goenka are justified since, should something go wrong in its India media unit, it will face severe consequences in the US and Japan where corporate governance standards are very strict.
“Even if Sony allows the merger to go ahead with Goenka at the helm, their biggest concern is the possibility of other serious allegations of irregularities coming out against him. The implications for Sony are massive in the US and Japan,” the person said.
Goenka has argued that the merger scheme agreed upon between the two parties should be implemented in its entirety. He has also reiterated that the Securities Appellate Tribunal has overturned the Sebi ban against him, which paves the path for him to become chief of Sony-Zee.
Sebi had barred Goenka and his father Subhash Chandra from holding directorships and top positions in any listed companies, including Sony-Zee.
“It looks very unlikely that Punit will settle for anything less than the MD & CEO posts of the merged entity, but he is also under pressure from ZEEL shareholders to conclude the merger at the earliest,” said another executive.
As per the merger scheme agreed upon between the two parties, Goenka was to serve as the MD & CEO of Sony-Zee for a period of five years from the effective date, subject to the terms and conditions as agreed between the two entities.
A legal expert said the middle path for both parties would be to allow the merger to proceed with Goenka as the MD & CEO. “Sony can always ask Goenka to step down if the allegations of financial irregularities come true after the Sebi investigation is concluded,” he said.

headline: What 'Pocahontas' tells us about Disney, for better and worse
content:
Disney's animated achievements -- certain ones -- are imprinted on our brains, in part because the company reminds us about them seemingly nonstop. Fresh from the
Disney
vault! Restored to its original glory!
"Wish," which arrived last month as part of Disney's centennial self-celebration, is a collection of callbacks to classics like "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" (1937), "
Sleeping Beauty
" (1959), "The Little Mermaid" (1989) and "
The Lion King
" (1994). Disney theme parks have recently unveiled attractions based on "
Frozen
" (2013) and "
Moana
" (2016), among others.
But there are also films in Disney's animated canon that the image-conscious company does not talk about much, and the reasons are usually obvious. Some were
box office
failures. A few of the older ones traffic in racist stereotypes.
If we are going to look back at Disney's history with animated movies, however, as the company has invited people to do with its 100th-anniversary bash, the problem films should be part of the discussion. To wrestle with Disney and its legacy -- the good and the bad, the past and the present -- the misfires sometimes offer as much insight as the masterworks.
Consider "Pocahontas."
Live Events
Released in 1995 at a time when Walt Disney Animation Studios was experiencing a creative renaissance, "Pocahontas" pulls from history and legend to recount -- sort of -- the story of the real-life Native American girl who, in 1607, supposedly saved an English settler, John Smith, after he'd been taken as prisoner by her father's tribe. The film won two Oscars (for song and score) and was celebrated by leading critics for its vibrant color palette and magical realism (a murmuration of autumn leaves, the advice-giving Grandmother Willow). Janet Maslin, reviewing the movie for The New York Times, called it a "landmark feat of animation."
"Pocahontas" also has some severe problems, starting with the title character. Disney depicted her not as a girl of about 11, as historians agree Pocahontas was at the time she interacted with Smith, but as an ultra-voluptuous young woman. Disney took other extreme liberties with the story, in particular inventing a romance between Pocahontas, who was voiced by Irene Bedard, and Smith (Mel Gibson). Disney higher-ups pressed the "Pocahontas" creative team to make it more like "Beauty and the Beast," which had been a runaway hit at the box office -- presto, a romance.
"Disney made a lot of unfortunate decisions with this movie," said Angela Aleiss, a film scholar whose books include "Hollywood's Native Americans: Stories of Identity and Resistance."
"It should be a lesson," she added of "Pocahontas," which was directed by Mike Gabriel and Eric Goldberg. "Why not let Indigenous people tell these stories?"
Recent Disney films like the animated "Strange World," with its gay teenage protagonist, have become cultural flashpoints. But "Pocahontas" prompted a full-blown fracas. Some people accused Disney of whitewashing history -- for leaving out the fact, for instance, that Pocahontas died at 21, perhaps of smallpox, after being taken to London and paraded around as an example of a "civilized savage." Others blasted "Pocahontas" for depicting some white settlers as bigoted plunderers (although historians would argue this was accurate). Some Native Americans winced at the ways in which the film perpetuated the Good Indian stereotype, which posits that worthy Native Americans were those who helped white immigrants. Psychologists complained that Disney's rendering of the hero gave girls yet another impossible body standard to live up to.
For these reasons, "Pocahontas" lives in a netherworld at Disney.
The company does not hide it. The movie is available on Disney+, and the character is designated an official Disney Princess. "Wish" contains a couple of subtle references to the film. But bring up "Pocahontas" at Disney headquarters, and people get visibly tense. The vibe is: Let's please change the subject. A couple of years ago, Disney decided that "Pocahontas" would be one of the few animated hits that would not be remade as a live-action spectacle. Too fraught, especially in the social media era. ("Pocahontas" was very much a hit. It cost about $112 million in today's dollars, and collected $707 million -- less than the Disney movies that preceded it, but a lot of dough all the same.)
Disney declined to comment for this article.
Animation historians contend that "Pocahontas" is more important than most people realize -- that the film's challenges have obscured its true standing in Disney's animated oeuvre.
"Pocahontas," for instance, "marked a new turn in Disney storytelling toward empowered heroines," said Mindy Johnson, an animation scholar whose books include "Ink & Paint: The Women of Walt Disney's Animation." Johnson added, "Many credit this to 'Mulan.' But 'Pocahontas' paved the way."
Despite its invented romance, the film ends with Pocahontas spurning Smith's invitation to go with him to England. She chooses to stay with her tribe.
"Pocahontas" was the first animated Disney film to focus on a woman of color. It was the first (and only) time that Disney made an animated movie about a real person. And in many ways, it was Disney's first overt "issues" movie for children. Developed in the aftermath of the 1992 Los Angeles riots, "Pocahontas" explored the idea that "if we don't learn to live with one another, we will destroy ourselves," as Peter Schneider, then Disney's animation president, put it in "The Art of Pocahontas" by Stephen Rebello.
"Environmental messages are equally present and so relevant, especially today," Johnson said.
Disney movies had always had a moral, but this went much further -- and the film's implicit political message freaked some people out: Disney is messing with our kids. The uproar helped push the company back toward lighter material, resulting in comedies like "The Emperor's New Groove" and "Lilo & Stitch."
A similar shift is going on right now at Disney. The company has become a political punching bag, partly because it has added openly gay, lesbian and queer characters to its animated movies. The emphasis on diversity in some of Disney's live-action films, including "The Little Mermaid," "The Marvels" and "Star Wars: The Last Jedi," has also led to fan complaints. Although Disney has also received positive feedback, the blowback -- and poor ticket sales for some of the films in question -- has prompted Disney to retrench.
"Creators lost sight of what their No. 1 objective needed to be," Disney CEO Bob Iger said at the Times' DealBook Summit last month. "We have to entertain first. It's not about messages."
It should be noted that "Pocahontas" has plenty of fans. Some point to the clever, sweeping ways in which the film's songs are visualized. Alan Menken ("The Little Mermaid") and Stephen Schwartz ("Wicked") wrote the music, which includes the Oscar-winning "Colors of the Wind," sung by Judy Kuhn.
"A graceful and well-intentioned entry in the Disney canon," Sophie Gilbert wrote in a 2015 essay in The Atlantic that defended the film as progressive and feminist. (The magazine also published letters from readers who did not agree.)
Hanay Geiogamah, a former director of the American Indian Studies Center at UCLA, was hired by Disney in the 1990s to consult on "Pocahontas" and its straight-to-video sequel, "Pocahontas II: Journey to a New World." In a phone interview, he called working with Disney "a really positive experience," noting that some of his concerns about authenticity (the depiction of dancing and ceremonies, for instance) led to prerelease changes in the film.
"I understood why people were upset, and, at the time, I made my voice heard, too," Geiogamah said. "But you have to remember, at the end of the day, this was a Disney animated fantasy. I was actually pleasantly surprised with how it turned out. Yes, there was a falsity at its core. But it also gave millions of young people a positive impression of Indian life. It wasn't all battles and ugliness and harshness."
The many opinions are a reminder of how powerful the Disney brand is: People care --
they really care
.
Affinity for the brand runs so deep that it can quickly recover when the company stumbles. Life in the Magic Kingdom goes on. Five months after "Pocahontas" arrived in theaters, tresses swinging, Disney released the first film from an experimental new animation company called Pixar. The movie was "Toy Story," and the response was so rapturous that "Pocahontas" -- and the fighting around it -- started to fade into history.

headline: ZEEL shareholders reject the reappointment of two independent directors
content:
Zee Entertainment Enterprises Limited
(
ZEEL
) shareholders have rejected the reappointment of Vivek
Mehra
and
Sasha Mirchandani
as independent directors at the annual general meeting (
AGM
) on Saturday while approving the appointment of Deepu Bansal as an independent director.
The special resolutions seeking the reappointment of Mehra and
Mirchandani
as independent directors didn't receive the requisite 75% yes votes from the shareholders.
Only 47.95% and 71% of the votes were cast in favour of the special resolution for the reappointment of Mehra and Mirchandani as independent directors. The special resolution for Bansal's appointment as an independent director was approved with 99.84% of the vote.
The ordinary resolution to appoint a director in place of Adesh Kumar Gupta, Non-Executive Director, who retires by rotation and, being eligible, offers himself for re-appointment, became infructuous due to his withdrawal from getting reappointed.
"The Board of Zee Entertainment Enterprises unanimously applauds Mr. Sasha Mirchandani and Mr. Vivek Mehra for their significant contribution made towards the company during their association. As two distinguished and noteworthy names in the corporate sector, Mr. Mirchandani and Mr. Mehra are on the boards of several leading publicly listed companies and have inculcated strong corporate governance ethics over the years," said ZEEL chairman R. Gopalan.

headline: Adani arm acquires majority stake in IANS India
content:
Adani Enterprises Ltd
has bought a 50.5% stake in IANS India, which owns and operates the newswire service Indo-Asian News Service (IANS), as the Adani Group solidifies its presence in the news
media business
.
The stake was purchased by
AMG Media Networks
, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Adani Enterprises. The company said the cost of the acquisition is Rs 5,10,000. However, sources indicate that the value may be higher.
In a regulatory filing, billionaire Gautam Adani-controlled Adani Enterprises said the stake comprised Category I and II shares with voting and non-voting rights, respectively. The remaining 49.5% stake will be held by
Sandeep Bamzai
, also the CEO and Editor-in-Chief of IANS.
According to the company, AMG Media will have operational and management control of IANS, and the right to appoint all directors of the newswire service.
"Adani will own a 50.5% stake in IANS, while I will retain the rest," Bamzai told ET, adding that Adani will buy the remaining stake over a period of time.

The share purchase agreement between AMG Media with IANS and Bamzai was signed on December 15.
IANS India has an authorized and paid-up share capital of Rs 20 lakh and Rs 10 lakh, respectively. The company recorded revenues of Rs 11.86 crore, Rs 9.38 crore, and Rs 10.33 crore in FY23, FY22, and FY21, respectively.
The IANS deal marks Adani Group's third major acquisition in the news media sector in two years. Within the media and entertainment sector, the group sees news media as a strategic area of importance.
The company's media arm, AMG Media Networks, acquired Raghav Bahl-promoted
Quintillion Business Media
in two separate transactions for a cumulative sum of over Rs 100 crore. It first took a 49% stake in March 2022 for Rs 47.8 crore and then bought the remaining 51% in August for Rs 52.45 crore.
Subsequently, the company acquired a 64.71% stake in Prannoy and Radhika Roy-promoted
NDTV
in separate transactions for a cash consideration of Rs 900.69 crore. NDTV owns and operates the news channels NDTV 24x7, NDTV India, and NDTV Profit, apart from the digital news platform NDTV.com. NDTV is accessible in 67 countries through a combination of dedicated feeds and content syndication.
Quintillion Business Media's digital business news platform, BQ Prime, has merged with NDTV Profit, which was relaunched recently as a TV and digital business news platform.
In its FY23 annual report, Adani Enterprises said news and information are the most powerful segments within the media and entertainment industry, despite being of a smaller size compared to other entertainment segments.
"News and information provides 1.4 billion Indians with relevant, credible, up-to-date, anytime/anywhere service on a device of their choice. Moreover, considering the interest of the world at large in India’s resurgence and economic potential, there is a growing need in this segment," the company stated.
Established in 1986, IANS has six business verticals, including IANS News Service (English and Hindi), IANS Multimedia, IANS Publishing, IANS Media Consultancy, IANS Software Services, and IANS Mobile Services.

headline: A Disney-Reliance India entertainment merger may be beset with antitrust headaches
content:
A merger of
Walt Disney
's India unit and billionaire
Mukesh Ambani
's media business would create an entertainment powerhouse in India, but lawyers say any deal would draw intense antitrust scrutiny and assets would likely need to be shed.
Disney and India's Reliance, which each have a major streaming service as well as 120 TV channels between them, are looking at merging into an entity in which Ambani's group would likely have a majority stake, sources said this week.
In particular, a deal could benefit Disney whose Hotstar streaming app has been loss-making. CEO Bob Iger said last month that while Disney's TV channels were doing well in India, other parts of the business were struggling and it was seeking to "improve the bottom line."
Also Read:
A 'Star' deal by Mukesh Ambani may give retail giants sleepless nights
If a deal was struck, it would be the second to seismically reshape India's TV and streaming landscape as Japan's Sony also plans to merge its India business with India's Zee Entertainment.

The Zee-Sony plan cleared a review by the Competition Commission of India (CCI) last year and could close in the coming weeks. The two companies have said they will divest three of Zee's Hindi TV channels as part of their agreement for regulatory acceptance.
Although Netflix and Amazon also compete in India's $28 billion media and entertainment market, the emergence of two behemoths would probably create a duopoly wielding anti-competitive power over advertisers, users and content creators, antitrust lawyers said.
"This deal may get closer scrutiny because of the increased concentration of market power post the Zee-Sony merger. That makes their path to CCI approval more challenging," said Avimukt Dar, founding partner at India's IndusLaw.
Disney declined to comment. Reliance, its broadcast unit Viacom18 and the CCI did not respond to Reuters queries.
One key area of regulatory scrutiny for a Disney-Reliance merger would be their streaming businesses and their power over advertising during cricket - a sport that commands fanatical devotion in India.
Disney Hotstar, India's biggest streaming app with 38 million users, owns the rights for International Cricket Council's matches in India until 2027, while Reliance's growing JioCinema app has the rights for popular cricket league IPL.
The CCI would be worried that the "combined entity, due to its strong market presence in streaming can command their own rates and advertisers will be left without bargaining power," said Vaibhav Choukse, head of competition law at Indian law firm JSA.
In TV too, there is much that might displease regulators.
Viacom18's 38 channels include Comedy Central and Nickelodeon, while Disney, whose Star brand has been a household name for decades in India, has 80.
Elara Capital estimates Disney and Viacom18 together will have the biggest share of the TV ads market at 43% while Zee-Sony would have 25%, making it difficult for others to compete.
Estimates from the CCI document approving the Zee-Sony merger also underscore the potential pricing power of a Disney and Viacom18 combination.
In Hindi entertainment channels, for example, as of last year Disney and Viacom18 had a combined share of 30% to 40%, compared with Zee-Sony's 30-35%, the document shows.
In local language Marathi channels, Disney had market share of 50-55% and when combined with Viacom18 that would rise to between 65% and 75%. In Bengali language entertainment channels, the two would command as much as 50% market share.
"If the market shares of the parties exceed 40-50% in any market, CCI is likely to conduct a detailed investigation," said Choukse.
While divesting certain channels would be an option to assuage CCI's concerns, the merged entity could also offer commitments to not raise ad rates for a certain period, according to Gautam Shahi of Dua Associates.

headline: Zee-Sony Merger: NCLAT refuses to halt mega merger to create media giant
content:
India's tribunal court has declined to issue a stay order on Zee Entertainment Enterprises Limited (ZEEL) and Sony's merger to create a $10 billion media giant, according to ET Now.
Shares of Zee rose following the news and hit day's high of Rs 286.50. It was last trading 1.6% higher on BSE Sensex, which continued its record rally and was up 0.7% at 70,980.
The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) has however issued notice in the plea challenging the mega merger. It has listed the case for hearing on January 8.
Creditors IDBI Bank and Axis Finance had earlier filed pleas against the merger of Zee Entertainment Enterprise with Culver Max Entertainment, formerly Sony Pictures Networks India. They had challenged the August 10, 2023, order of the Mumbai bench of the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) to approve the merger. The NCLT, in its decision to approve the merger, rejected requests from financial institutions like IDBI Trusteeship, IDBI Bank, Axis Finance, JC Flowers Asset Reconstruction Co, and Imax Corp.
IDBI and Axis Finance contested this decision by appealing to the NCLAT.

headline: Influencers lawyer up to help protect personal brands
content:
Priya Raina, an actor, singer, and
social media
influencer, is contemplating launching her label to bring Kashmiri crafts and arts into the mainstream. However, before that, she is making rounds at the lawyer's offices to make sure her brand as a social media influencer remains solid and intact.
"I have made conscious efforts to increasingly use original content on social media and now when planning my label, I want to make sure that even my social media profile remains protected from any copycats or imposters," said Raina. "When corporates or brands approach me for any collaboration, I have started to consult lawyers to make sure that IPR (intellectual property rights) regarding my social media profile remains solid," she further added.
Increasingly more and more social media
influencers
are reaching out to lawyers to protect
IP rights
that they have created on social media and to negotiate better
contracts
with brands and agencies.
Content creators from the field of cooking to beauty and auto to fitness, on platforms such as Meta-owned
Instagram
or Alphabet-owned YouTube, are seeking lawyers' help to protect their IP rights to help them protect brands and even negotiate contracts with brands and other third parties.
Live Events
"We are witnessing a trend where many social media influencers are approaching lawyers as they feel many brands are misusing their IP rights," said Viraj Sheth, co-founder and CEO of talent management and digital media firm
Monk Entertainment
. "Albeit, most such influencers are still unaware of their rights."
Monk Entertainment manages over 100 creators across diverse categories of fashion, food, comedy, music, and lifestyle including Niharika NM, Your Food Lab, Yashraj Mukhate, and Madan Gowri.
The influencer marketing industry's value is estimated to reach '2,200 crore by 2025, according to a report by influencer.in.
Experts feel that the awareness is not restricted to protecting the influencer's identity but some of them are making efforts to translate it into consumer brands, which has led to this trend.
Priyanka Khimani, founder of media & entertainment advisory law firm Khimani & Associates, recognised that influencers in India are rapidly catching up with the Western trend of protecting their IP rights. "Increasingly, we are seeing many influencers becoming entrepreneurs and launching their own brands and product lines; or seeking equity participation to promote or invest in other brands and ventures. This is typically when they seek legal help" said Khimani.
"Often, when social media influencers jump on an ongoing trend to create branded content, they inadvertently infringe someone else's IP rights and, in those situations too, they reach out to lawyers to try and figure out a solution," she added.
Meghna Kamdar, who runs the channel 'Meghna's Food Magic' on platforms such as YouTube and Instagram said she's contemplating consulting lawyers for a host of issues.
"A lot of handles download our content and post on their handle without permission; and by removing our names," said Kamdar. "I am not worried about my brand, because I am a brand. But yes, people do create handles of look-alike names, which we get taken down. Having said that, if I were to do some merchandise or products etc. in future, then yes, it would definitely be an area where legal protection would be needed," she adds.

headline: BBC India restructures to create new entity to comply with FDI rules
content:
Four
BBC
staff members on Tuesday announced plans to leave the organisation and form a
new entity
in India named Collective Newsroom, which will provide services "as commissioned by the BBC" and in compliance with the country's foreign direct investment (FDI) rules. According to a statement from the UK-based public service broadcaster,
Collective Newsroom
has been established as an
Indian company
that is wholly owned by Indian citizens. It replaces
BBC World Service India
to continue to provide language-based content.
The move follows the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) premises in India facing "surveys" by tax authorities and an ensuing investigation by the Enforcement Directorate (ED) over alleged FDI violations earlier this year.
"The establishment of Collective Newsroom Private Limited ensures the BBC and Collective Newsroom can meet their shared commitment to Indian audiences and cover stories on India that matter to global audiences. It is in compliance with the Indian Foreign Direct Investment law," reads the BBC statement.
"Collective Newsroom has been established as an Indian company, wholly owned by Indian citizens, with four existing staff members leaving the BBC to lead Collective Newsroom. These senior leaders have a wealth of editorial and programme-making experience," it said.
"The BBC will commission Collective Newsroom to produce its six Indian language services as well as Indian digital output and
Indian YouTube
channel in English for audiences globally," it added.

headline: BBC World India to rejig shareholding, seeks time till end of FY24 to ensure compliance with FDI norm
content:
Mumbai: BBC World Service India, 99.99% owned by the British Broadcasting Corp (BBC), is restructuring its shareholding to comply with the Centre's foreign direct investment (FDI) guidelines. These limit foreign holdings in digital news entities to 26%.
BBC News deputy chief executive
Jonathan Munro
is likely to make an announcement on the purported change in ownership structure soon, said people in the know. He is scheduled to address a townhall of
BBC India
staff on Tuesday.
Replying to ET's questions, a BBC spokesperson said, "We will not be making an announcement today. We will let you know if and when we have more to say."
Munro couldn't be immediately reached for comment.

In its regulatory filings, BBC World Service India disclosed that it had received a letter from the ministry of information and broadcasting dated March 31, for alleged non-compliance with FDI norms. The company said it has sought time until March 31, 2024, for compliance, and communicated its restructuring proposals to the ministry.
People aware of the development told ET that one of the options being explored by the company is to offer stakes to some of its executives. Some key functionaries in India include Rupa Jha, head of BBC News India; Mukesh Sharma, head of African language services, BBC News; and Sanjoy Mazumdar, deputy managing editor, Asia, at BBC World Service.
BBC World Service India acts as a service provider to BBC UK for the production of television, radio and website content in Hindi and other Indian regional languages, as well as English. In FY23, the company earned a service fee of Rs 129.4 crore from BBC UK for content produced, and a programming fee of Rs 77 lakh from licensing content to radio stations, TV channels and digital platforms.
Under the Scanner
In September 2019, the Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT) capped FDI in digital news at 26% under the government approval route.
The broadcasting ministry issued a public notice on November 16, 2020, asking all eligible digital news entities with foreign investment over 26% to take the necessary steps to bring the foreign investment down to 26% by October 15, 2021.
In February, BBC World Service India and BBC Global News India premises were surveyed by income tax officials. Subsequently, the Directorate General of GST Intelligence issued a notice for investigation. The Directorate of Enforcement (ED) had also issued notices to the two companies in April under provisions of the Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999.
"Pending the ongoing discussions with the ministry and ED, it is not possible, at this stage, to reliably estimate the consequent implications, including provisions, if any, that may need to be recognised in the financial statement," BBC World Service said in its filing for FY23.
In its annual report,
BBC Group
noted that a potential contingent liability had been identified following the commencement of the Indian government's tax survey on BBC activities in the country in February this year. It added that the company had cooperated in full, and will continue to do so, with all demands, including document and information requests, supported by its external legal and tax advisers.
As part of its residual risk and 2023-24 planned activities, the company said it will undertake the implementation of a remedial plan to adhere to local laws and regulations in India.
Distribution & Services
BBC Global News India acts as the distributor of BBC World News and the CBeebies Channel and is also a service provider to BBC Global News for advertising, sales and marketing activities in various territories, including India.
The company said the BBC World News channel was granted downlinking permission in India from the broadcasting ministry till July 7. It added that the application seeking permission for the next 10 years has been filed. It has had its annual permission renewed for the downlinking of children's entertainment TV channel CBeebies until April 2, 2024.
In FY23, BBC Global News India recorded revenue and profit of Rs 43.4 crore and Rs 1.3 crore, respectively.
Early this year, the government banned a BBC documentary on the Prime Minister that had been broadcast in the UK, calling it propaganda.

headline: SC agrees to hear IDBI Trusteeship Services’ appeal, issues notice to Essel group entities
content:
The
Supreme Court
on Monday sought response from
Essel
group firms - Cyquator Media Services Pvt Ltd and Direct Media Distribution Ventures on the
IDBI
Trusteeship Services’ appeal against a National Company Law Appellate Tribunal’s (
NCLAT
) September order that rejected its
insolvency plea
against the firms.
A bench led by Chief Justice DY Chandrachud posted the matter for further hearing after four weeks.
On September 12, the appellate tribunal had dismissed an insolvency petition against
Direct Media Ventures
and two days later, it also rejected the insolvency petition against Cyquator Media, a promoter group company of
Zee Entertainment Enterprises
. The NCLAT had noted that the default took place in June 2020, which was covered under the period of exclusion under Section 10A from insolvency and bankruptcy cases due to COVID-19.
Challenging the NCLAT’s order, IDBI through counsel Gaurav Mitra and Nagarkatti Kartik Uday asked the SC to consider “whether the sale of the pledged shares subsequent to the suspension period under Section 10A, amounts to a fresh cause of action entitling it to file a Section 7 petition and further whether the bar under Section 10A whittles down or dilutes the obligations of a corporate debtor under a corporate guarantee, which is continuing and subsisting and under which obligations of the corporate debtor are not discharged, released, impaired or otherwise affected by reason of any legal limitation, till the discharge of all obligations of the corporate debtor.”
Essel Infraprojects, another Essel group company, had proposed to issue 425 rated, unlisted, redeemable, non-convertible debentures aggregating a nominal value of Rs 425 crore. IDBI Trusteeship had agreed to act as debenture trustee. A debenture trust deed was executed between
IDBI Trusteeship Services and Essel
for which Cyquator Media and Direct Media Ventures jointly stood as corporate guarantors. Last year, IDBI Trusteeship issued a demand notice to Direct Media and Cyquator to make payment of Rs 592 crore with 12% interest. While it filed an insolvency plea against Cyquator for default in payment in May 2022, the National Company Law Tribunal dismissed the IDBI Trusteeship's insolvency plea in June 2023.
Live Events
The appeal filed by Manilal Kher Ambalal and Co stated that after the dismissal of petitions, which were filed by the two entities against its notice of demand, by the Delhi High Court, IDBI had invoked the pledge of securities and sold 43,47,500 pledged shares of ZEE Entertainment Enterprises in the open market in various tranches and realized Rs 92.34 crore and accordingly gave credit to that effect to Essel.
It further contended that while the appellate authority without considering the facts of the case had upheld the NCLT’s order, it had
held that the Section 7 petition was barred by Section 10A of the IBC, on the ground that the liability of the two Essel entities to make the outstanding payment arose on the date of invocation of the guarantee, i.e., on June 12, 2020, as per which June 16, 2020 was the date on which the default was committed.

headline: Tata Play delivers a 'breakthrough' for targeted ads on TVs to likely enjoy advertising revenues
content:
Tata Play
on Monday rolled out
addressable ads
for linear television, a 'breakthrough' in the Indian industry for unconnected boxes and a move that should propel revenues of the
dish tv
provider who never had access to advertising revenue.
Addressable Ads will allow brands to target segmented audiences with same TV ad spots, the company said. In simple terms, broadcasters can now choose which ads to play for which audience of varied regions and income groups.
Invidi is the ad-tech and campaign management partner fo Tata Play, which has also partenred with TAM for audience measurement and monitoring.
"This breakthrough marks a first for unconnected boxes, empowering advertisers to reach their targeted audience with complete measurability," the company said in a statement. "The segmentation will be based on audience profiles and various geographical cuts, making television advertising more engaging and effective."

Targeting advertising in India capitalises on user engagement, proving to be a cost-effective and efficient method for businesses aiming to engage a receptive audience and drive sales.
"While television delivers the highest advertising reach for brands, it doesn’t offer sharper targeting. With our targeted ad delivery, we can now split a TV spot into multiple beams with each beam carrying messages to distinctive audience cohorts, as required by the advertisers,” said Nagpal.

headline: Broadcasting Bill may lead to regulatory issues: IBDF President K Madhavan
content:
K. Madhavan
, who is also the chief of
Disney Star
, was recently re-elected as the president of the Indian Broadcasting & Digital Foundation (
IBDF
) for the third time. In an interview with
ET
's Javed Farooqui, Madhavan expressed concerns about the draft Broadcasting Services Regulation Bill (BSRB) put out by the Ministry of Information & Broadcasting (MIB) for public consultation and its impact on creative freedom. He also feels that both pay-TV and OTT will continue to co-exist as they complement each other. Excerpts:
You have been re-elected as IBDF president for the third time. What will be your key priorities going forward?
As IBDF, we have made significant progress over the last couple of years by partnering with regulators and policymakers to create a more conducive environment for the M&E industry. In our interactions with the MIB and regulators, we have highlighted the need for light touch regulation, especially in the context of the content self-regulatory framework, market-driven pricing and forbearance on distribution framework, a
National Broadcasting Policy
(NBP), and developing India as a global content and tech hub.
We have also highlighted the need to recognize, protect, and uphold the primacy of intellectual property rights protection in content-driven industries and sector-specific copyright enforcement measures. As an industry, our priorities are to facilitate industry stakeholders to grow the M&E sector to $100 billion by the year 2030.
Last year, we played a pivotal role in the notification of New Tariff Order (NTO) 3.0, and we have furthered the cause of the industry by highlighting concerns on key issues including spectrum auction for 5G deployment in C Band and concerns around convergence of the broadcasting sector with telecom.

We have put in place a robust system of self-regulation of broadcast and digital content, and I remain confident of moving to an environment of regulatory forbearance with light touch regulation that will allow participants in the M&E industry to adapt and evolve more nimbly.
What are your views on the Broadcast Services Regulation Bill and its impact on the M&E sector?
As you are already aware, it’s been only a few weeks since the bill was put up for public consultation and we are in the process of reviewing its contents. The Bill as released by MIB for public consultation, needs a serious relook and we have requested some time to revert with our comments. In July, the MIB had requested TRAI to give its recommendations on a NBP, that would define the vision, mission, and policy principles for the broadcasting industry. IBDF is of the view that a new policy should be designed that is flexible enough to be applied to a wide range of situations and allows for innovation and creativity to grow the industry.
By consolidating various guidelines and rules for TV, Radio, and OTT, the bill is attempting to force-fit these services, especially the video streaming services provided by OTT, into a linear broadcasting framework. This could result in structural issues in their regulation.
For instance, the Bill defines “broadcasting” as a “one-to-many” transmission and includes OTT platforms, which use one-to-one transmissions. Additionally, the Bill categorizes “OTT broadcasting service operators” as “broadcasting network operators” (BNOs), whereas it is the telecom and internet service providers that operate the networks, unlike linear broadcasting where DPOs operate and manage the network.
Television is a medium where viewers consume content as per a prescribed schedule. OTT services are pull-based, with consumers making informed choices about the time and type of content they want to watch. Bringing OTT under the same regulatory framework will undermine this distinctive feature of OTT.
Also, the Bill by adding the additional requirement of Content Evaluation Committees and government oversight through a Broadcast Advisory Council will not only curb creative freedom on OTT but will end up micro-managing content creation and programming in both TV and OTT. This should be looked at through the existing industry self-regulatory bodies like BCCC and DMCRC which have been in existence for almost a decade and have played a pivotal role in regulating content without hampering creative freedom.
You met PM Modi in July. What were the key issues that you discussed with him?
One of the key issues that was discussed with the Prime Minister was the need to introduce a national policy on media and entertainment for the enhancement of the broadcasting industry which would allow for more efficient functioning and monitoring of the industry, benefitting both industry participants as well as regulatory bodies. The Prime Minister was very laudatory of the role that the industry has played in raising the profile of local sports like Kabaddi in the country and was keen that we develop India as a sporting nation, going much beyond just cricket.
The M&E sector is undergoing considerable transformation because of the convergence of technology, telecom, and media. How will convergence affect the industry?
Technology has proven to be a huge disruptor, not just in the M&E industry, but across every industry, the end beneficiary being the consumer. However, within the media & entertainment industry, we need to view this in context. We have two significant mediums – TV and OTT – that while largely serving similar audiences, are very different. TV is a push-based medium that is based on appointment viewing while OTT is a pull-based medium that allows the viewer to watch the content of their choice at the time of their choice and convenience. The draft Broadcast Services Regulation Bill 2023 has suggested that these mediums be brought under a single regulatory framework, but we are not in favour of this approach.
Broadcast sector profitability has come under stress due to a subdued ad market and sluggish growth in subscription revenue. How do you see FY24 and FY25 panning out for the sector as a whole?
The broadcast sector has no doubt faced some challenges since the last quarter of the calendar year 2022, fuelled in large part by global macroeconomic factors such as inflationary pressures and the disruption of global supply chains due to certain geopolitical events. From an advertisement revenue standpoint as well, we saw some of the traditional advertisers such as the start-up eco-system, automobile companies, and more recently, online betting platforms stay away from TV advertising and while that did create a temporary vacuum, we are seeing a gradual revival. During the current festive season, we’ve seen early signs of revival compared to last year and expect that this will hold up in the months ahead.
Nearly a third of Indian households do not yet have a television set and as income and aspiration levels grow, we expect these households to gradually come into the Pay TV universe. India is expected to grow 6.3% in FY24 – the fastest-growing major economy in the world – the financial markets are at all-time highs which is reflective of the hugely positive sentiment regarding the prospects of the Indian economy, and we expect that the M&E industry is going to be a natural beneficiary of this broad-based growth. We remain bullish about the broadcast sector in the near to medium term.
The pay-TV subscriber base has been on the decline in the last few years. Where do the pay-TV numbers stand today, and have the industry's efforts to stem the decline made any impact?
It is true that as we came out of the Covid period, there was some moderation in the Pay TV universe. However, in the current financial year, we’ve seen a 6 million increase in the number of Pay TV connections to reach a total of 173 million households as per BARC data. So, while there have been reports suggesting that the emergence of OTT has hurt the Pay TV universe, BARC data suggests otherwise. That tells you that TV continues to remain a very strong viewing medium in India, quite unlike developed markets where Pay TV households have been on the decline. This is the only market where TV and digital are growing and the two are complementing each other, especially in the content space. Of course, it is important to bear in mind that broadcasters continue to grapple with the serious issue of under-reporting of Pay TV data by distributors. Content piracy is another serious issue that is standing in the way of the Pay TV industry.
Did the price hike last year impact the overall pay-TV base?
The price hike has not had any adverse impact on the user base. It has grown, which reflects the continued strength of TV as a medium, underpinned by the compelling and engaging content that broadcasters have been serving to their audiences. It has also helped increase the subscription revenues of distributors and broadcasters after a four-year hiatus. This in turn allows us to make more meaningful investments in content and technology. Let us not forget that content costs have escalated severalfold during this period, especially the rights cost for sports and movies.
Where do you see the M&E sector in the next few years?
The M&E industry is presently at Rs 2.1 trillion and is poised to grow to a size of INR2.8trn by the year 2025 – a CAGR of 10.5%. However, the aspiration is for the media & entertainment industry to grow to a size of Rs 8 trillion ($100 billion) by the year 2030, aided by a supportive policy regime. We see secular growth for both TV and Digital over the next few years, with Digital growing at a faster pace than TV. The M&E sector plays a critical role in job creation, both, by way of direct and indirect job creation, and has significant headroom for growth considering that ad revenue presently makes up less than 0.5% of the country’s GDP as opposed to greater than 1% in most developed markets. India has huge potential in establishing itself as an international content and talent hub given the cutting-edge technology it already deploys in the production and post-production of content as well as the superior tech talent that the country has. In the years ahead, the M&E industry is going to play an even more significant role in enhancing India’s soft power on the world stage through powerful storytelling that profiles the country’s rich and diverse culture and heritage.
Despite the sector's common concerns, television channels and distributors remain at odds. Why is this the case?
We’re not at loggerheads of any sort with distributors. Post-NTO, there has been a huge decline in the number of disputes between broadcasters and distributors. We strongly believe that all stakeholders, including distributors, should work together for the betterment of the industry. On a working level, there could be minor disagreements that are being addressed on an ongoing basis. The regulator, TRAI, is also playing a major role in resolving some of the issues like audit of distribution platforms.
While big broadcasters have pulled out GECs offering re-run programming from DD Free Dish, the platform continues to grow at pay-TV's expense. Will there be a rethink of putting channels back on DD Free Dish, or will you continue to keep GECs off DD Free Dish?
Let us understand that these are two different platforms. Pay TV is not in any sort of competition with Free Dish. We see Free Dish as being complementary to Pay TV. Most of the content on Free Dish channels is re-purposed Pay TV content.
Per capita income in India is increasing steadily, and over the last eight years has increased by over 35% to just under Rs 1 lakh. As household incomes increase and aspiration levels of people in semi-urban and rural areas grow, we expect to see a migration of the user base from Free Dish to Pay TV. Further, I would like to draw your attention to the BARC data which suggests that Free Dish households have seen a decline.
When do you expect the broadcast sector to get infrastructure status?
Gaining infrastructure status has been a long pending demand of the industry and we would welcome being accorded this status as it would allow for larger capital outlays to build on an already robust broadcast and digital eco-system.

headline: Removal of safe harbour provisions will harm small firms the most: Google Executive
content:
NEW DELHI: The complete removal of
safe harbour
provisions that give
social media
and internet intermediaries protection from third-party content will harm smaller firms the most and they can become very hesitant about innovating new products and services, a senior
Google
executive told ET.
"A framework that has a safe harbour from being responsible for all the content that's travelling over your systems is a cornerstone to ensuring innovation and investment in those technologies. If a company is liable for everything that is going across their system, they can be very hesitant about growing products and services to facilitate content," the vice president of government affairs and public policy at Google,
Markham Cho Erickson
said.
Though the idea behind safe harbour as a safety mechanism for social media and other internet intermediaries against third-party content "is a good principle", it should not be an excuse for companies to avoid being regulated by the government or from the roles and responsibilities intermediaries have to protect against inappropriate or unlawful or harmful third party content, he said.
"The trend is to not do away with the concept that only people developing bad content should be responsible for the bad content, but that companies that are the fiduciaries have responsibilities. The government should have some way of verifying that those responsibilities (of social media intermediaries) are being executed," Erickson said, adding that he looked forward to discussion with the government on these regulations as and when they are included in the Digital India Act.
The government has proposed to replace the 23-year-old Information Technology Act of 2000 with a new legislation which is more suited to the changed face of the internet.

India, which is going to be a global leader in
AI technology

headline: TV18, E18 to merge with Network18
content:
Reliance Industries-owned media conglomerate
Network18
is merging its subsidiaries
TV18
, which owns a 13.54% stake in Viacom18, and e-Eighteen.com (
E18
), which owns
moneycontrol
, into itself to create a single listed entity.
Following the amalgamation of TV18 into Network18, the former will be dissolved without winding up. TV18 is currently a listed entity on both the BSE and the NSE.
The board of directors of the respective companies approved the scheme of arrangements at their meetings held today.
As part of the merger scheme, TV18 shareholders will get 100 equity shares of Rs 5 each of Network18 for every 172 shares that they own in the company.
Likewise, E18 shareholders will receive 19 equity shares of Rs. 5 each of Network18 for every 1 equity share of Rs. 10 each.

headline: Reliance-owned TV18 Broadcast to merge with Network18
content:
Reliance-owned TV18 Broadcast Limited (TV18) on Wednesday announced a scheme of arrangement in terms of which TV18 and
e-Eighteen.com Limited
(“E18”, which owns and operates
MoneyControl
website and app) will merge with
Network18
.
The proposed scheme will consolidate TV and
digital
news businesses of the Network18 group in one company. "It will help create India’s largest platform-agnostic news media powerhouse with the widest footprint across languages, straddling both TV and Digital. It will enable Network18 to consolidate and further grow its business from a position of strength. This will present a unique opportunity to all shareholders to participate in the media business of the group through one listed entity," the company said in an exchanges filing.
The merged entity will comprise of the TV portfolio of TV18 (20 news channels in 16 languages and CNBCTV18.com), Digital assets of Network18 (News18.com platform across 13 languages and Firstpost) as also MoneyControl website and app. Viacom18 with its portfolio of
JioCinema
and 40 TV channels will be a direct subsidiary of Network18. Network18 will continue to hold its investment in BookMyShow.

headline: Dish TV's Watcho hits 3 million paid subscriber base
content:
Watcho,
Dish TV
's OTT aggregation platform, has added 1 million new subscribers in the last few months to cross the 3 million paid subscriber milestone. In August, Watcho had crossed the 2 million paid subscriber mark.
Watcho has amassed 90 million users since its launch in 2022. The platform offers bundled packages of leading OTT platforms under a single subscription along with its exclusive content under ‘Watcho Exclusives’.
The OTT aggregator has partnerships with 16 popular platforms such as Disney+ Hotstar,
ZEE5
, SonyLIV, Lionsgate Play, Hungama Play,
HoiChoi
, Chaupal, Manorama Max, FanCode, Raj Digital, Tarang Plus, ShortsTV, ETV Win, Stage, Aao Nxt, and ‘Watcho Exclusives’.
Watcho also offers over 45 web series, Swag (user-generated content), popular shows, and exclusive live TV across genres such as romance, corporate conspiracies, family drama, fantasy, adventure, and sci-fi, providing seamless access to premium content.
Commenting on the milestone achievement, Dish TV India CEO Manoj Dobhal said, "As we celebrate the achievement of 3 million paid subscriptions on Watcho's OTT Super App, it's a moment of pride and gratitude. At Dish TV and Watcho, we are committed to creating a new immersive content experience for our users and driving business growth through innovative new business streams."

headline: FanCode looks to double its paid subscriber base in 2024: Co-founder Yannick Colaco
content:
Dream Sports-owned sports streaming platform
FanCode
, which claims having 100 million users, is looking to double its paid subscriber base in 2024, a top company executive said.
"Our user base grew by over five times in the last three years, and we expect our subscriber base to grow over 2x in 2024 vs. 2023," said
Yannick Colaco
, co-founder of FanCode, which received $50 million in funding from
Dream Sports
in 2021.
In recent times, FanCode has partnered with content aggregators like Prime Video Channels, Airtel XStream and Watcho to reach new audiences and acquire more paid subscribers.
Launched in April 2019, FanCode's revenue model is built around subscription. However, it also allows limited targeted advertising, which helps brands connect with premium-paying audiences.
"Our business model is predicated on a strong subscription model that leverages this D2C relationship and is supported with contextual advertising," Colaco said.
Live Events
He noted that the free streaming strategy adopted by JioCinema and Disney+ Hotstar is good for the sports content ecosystem as it will expand the market.
According to Colaco, India has over 600 million sports fans, of whom 136 million are avid fans who consume some sport multiple times a week.
FanCode is looking to attract avid sports fans to its platform and offer content that is relevant to them. Apart from cricket and football, the platform also live streams kabaddi, volleyball, basketball and boxing.
"We want to help the sports ecosystem grow. This is part of the Dream Sports vision and is something we continue to strive for every day at FanCode," Colaco said while noting that sports fandom in India is still at a nascent stage.
In line with its strategy to tap into different sporting communities, FanCode streamed over 20,000 matches in 17 different sports, which is higher than the 5,000 matches across nine sports last year.
"We want to be able to get more users across different sports. Next year, we are going to have cricket, football and a whole lot of other sports throughout the year," he said.
FanCode's content acquisition strategy is dictated by data and analytics, and it works on different models with official sporting bodies, including revenue share and licence fees.
"As we grow our user base and consumption, we can use that data to continuously improve our decision-making in acquiring more content relevant to our users," Colaco said.
FanCode is also betting on the sports merchandise business in India. It works with eight IPL teams and runs online megastores for Kolkata Knight Riders, Punjab Kings and Rajasthan Royals.
It also has a two-year partnership with the International Cricket Council (ICC) and a licence to sell merchandise for global football teams such as Paris Saint-Germain, FC Barcelona and Man City.
"The problem we were trying to solve in launching the sports merchandise business was similar. We found that avid sports fans did not have access to fan gear for sports brands that they loved," he said.
